doc.title: FY25 model update; strategy becoming clearer but outlook tough
doc.source_uri: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.2 普通个人版/Barclays/Boohoo FY25 model update strategy becoming clearer but outlook toughBoohoo FY25 model update strategy becoming clearer b_2025-08-29

passages.text: MT strategy clearer, but execution will take time and outlook remains challenged. PLT sale could unlock some value, though we expect any valuation to be materially below what Boohoo originally paid & no obvious buyer at this stage. Valuation challenging with lack of +ve NT FCF/EPS. UW.

Boohoo is in the early stages of a multi- year turnaround strategy. Performance recovery of the company now rests on three key pillars: scaling Debenhams' asset- light marketplace model across the Group, expanding margins, and 'right- sizing' the Youth Brands, which we view as the most structurally challenged. While Debenhams is showing encouraging growth, its current scale is small ( \(\sim\) 650m GMV). We remain cautious on the feasibility of replicating the asset- light model across the Youth Brands, where operational complexity and brand positioning may limit its effectiveness. Although the mid- term strategy is becoming clearer, we believe it will take time to translate into results, and Boohoo's outlook remains challenged.

A potential sale of PLT could unlock some value for the Group. Boohoo has classified PLT as an asset held for sale, with FY25 sales of approximately £420m ( \(\sim\) 24% YoY) and an adjusted EBITDA loss of \(\sim\) 2m (albeit we understand that this has now tipped slightly profitable in in 1HFY26E). Boohoo currently trades at \(\sim\) 0.2x FY26E EV/Sales. Given PLT's faster top- line decline and loss- making profile, we think it is fair to apply a haircut to Group valuation and, assuming a 0.15x EV/Sales multiple ( \(\sim\) 25% haircut), this implies a potential valuation of \(\sim\) 60m versus Boohoo's EV of \(\sim\) 200m. This is materially below the \(\sim\) 270m Boohoo paid for the remaining 34% stake in 2020, which valued PLT closer to \(\sim\) 800m. While asset sales could support the balance sheet, Boohoo's fulfilment strategy remains unclear, with the company still evaluating "all long- term options" for its US and Burnley DCs. Until this is resolved, we remain cautious on the near- term deleveraging potential from any PLT sale, particularly given the Group's high fixed cost base and lower volumes.
This research report has been prepared in whole or in part by equity research analysts based outside the US who are not registered/qualified as research analysts with FINRA.
Please see analyst certifications and important disclosures beginning on page 9. Completed: 28- Aug- 25, 21:33 GMT Released: 29- Aug- 25, 03:00 GMT Restricted - External
Equity Research European Internet 29 August 2025
Potential Upside/Downside
Source: Bloomberg, Barclays Research
Shares Outstanding (mn)

Source: IDC Link to Barclays Live for interactive charting

It is also not immediately obvious who a potential buyer could be: Management flagged the Topshop sale last year as a reference point and noted the reported interested parties in the Topshop asset (ABG, Shein). We think Shein may be unlikely given how Shein is one of Boohoo's closest competitors. Meanwhile, Frasers (Boohoo's largest shareholder) have previously voiced concern about asset disposals/sales, potentially signalling their interest in the Group assets (see Our initial thoughts on Boohoo/Frasers Group situation, Oct 2024). That said, given Frasers recent public tensions with Boohoo (most recently calling for the Chair to step down, source: Retail Gazette 14/08/2025), we do not see a sale to Frasers as the most likely outcome. With no obvious buyer at this stage, and PLT declining 20% and loss-making, we think Boohoo may struggle to sell the asset in the short term.

For context, Topshop was sold at \(\sim 1x\) EV/Sales in Oct 24 (see No longer just a re- fi story; d/g to UW) despite declining mid- teens, with Shein's reported offer (link) valuing it closer to \(\sim 1.2x\) . While PLT is a larger asset in revenue terms versus Topshop, we think a similar valuation is unlikely given more pronounced top- line declines and heightened competitive risk. Unlike the Topshop/Hartland deal (which we viewed as essentially a shareholder equity injection), we think any independent buyer of PLT would likely seek a higher discount to reflect a weaker financial profile. In our base case, we assume a valuation closer to Group levels ( \(\sim 0.2x\) ) but acknowledge that there could be upside to this, which would likely be taken positively by the market.

Picture continues to look challenged for the group. UK Barclays Spend Trend signals for 18- 29- year- olds (Boohoo's target demographic) show UK fashion spend amongst this cohort is still weak (albeit improving slightly), Boohoo has the highest US tariff exposure within our coverage, and the company screens most at risk in our EU fashion coverage of direct risk from competition from Shein, which we think could get worse into 2H (see Digging into Shein UK filings). Against this backdrop, we think it will be difficult for Boohoo to return to growth in the near term. We cut our growth expectations for FY26 to \(\sim LSD\%\) declines and to LSD% growth in FY27, but note the lack of visibility and we continue to see downside risk.

Changes to estimates: Outlined in full in the back of this note, we: 1) split out GMV build by brand and build out revenue and GMV from this split; 2) introduce 1HFY26E forecasts; 3) introduce PLT forecasts and split out continuing/discontinued operations; 4) lower adj EBITDA (incl PLT) forecasts in FY26/27E by \(\sim 30 / 25\%\) , respectively, given lower growth forecasts and slightly lower gross margin estimates; and 5) trim our PT to 13p (previously 21p) based on the lower forecasts.

Valuation: We still don't forecast positive FCF (post SBC, leases) until FY27 and positive EPS until FY29. Boohoo trades on \(\sim 7x\) '26E EV/EBITDA - more expensive than Zalando ( \(\sim 5x\) ), which has both FCF and EPS making a valuation easier to underpin. The balance sheet is looking better post- refi but is still stretched (net debt at FY25 of \(\sim \pm 78m\) ). We prefer names in our coverage with positive and accelerating growth, well capitalised balance sheets, and near- term FCF/EPS support.

We make the following changes to our forecasts:
·Input FY25A results;
·Introduce 1HFY26E forecasts;
Price (28-Aug-2025) **GBp 16**
Price Target **GBp 13**
**Why UNDERWEIGHT?**

Boohoo can continue to grow, but we think that 1) near term, it faces the most severe headwinds among peers, and 2) longer term, growth will likely come at a higher cost than MT guidance implies. We see value here, but we also see risks skewed to the downside and expect things to get worse before they get better
**Upside case** **GBp 70**
Our upside scenario assumes Boohoo grows at low-double digits into the mid-term and expands margins to ~6%.
**Downside case** **GBp 9**
Our downside case assumes Boohoo's growth slows further marketplace struggles to scale, and significant investment is required to reaccelerate the business
**Upside/Downside scenarios**
·Build out GMV down to revenue splits - our revenue and gross margin forecasts are now driven from our detailed GMV build;
·Build out explicit PLT forecasts (currently held for sale);
·Cut growth expectations for FY26E and in outer years given weaker performance than expected in FY25;
·Nudge down gross margin expectations driven by lower gross margins in Youth Brands to reflect higher discounting, partially offset by higher gross margins as marketplace scales; and
·Lower gross profit forecasts, which are partially offset by some efficiency gains in opex,resulting in our adj EBITDA forecasts (incl PLT) declining by ~33/26%/27% in FY26/27/28E, respectively.

Overweight - The stock is expected to outperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Equal Weight - The stock is expected to perform in line with the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Underweight - The stock is expected to underperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Positive - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are improving.
Neutral - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are steady, neither improving nor deteriorating.
Negative - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are deteriorating.

Historical stock prices and price targets may have been adjusted for stock splits and dividends.
Valuation Methodology: We value Boohoo on a DCF with \(3\%\) terminal growth and an \(11.6\%\) WACC, with a \(12\%\) terminal ROCE.

Risks which May Impede the Achievement of the Barclays Research Valuation and Price Target: Risks to the upside include 1) faster growth than we anticipate - particularly internationally, 2) better- than- expected contribution from recent M&A, 3) supply chain improvements, and 4) more moderate competition.

This means there are different ways to evaluate a company or an investment and so different values may be placed on certain sustainability credentials as well as adverse ESG- related impacts of companies and ESG controversies. The evolving nature of sustainable investing considerations, models and methodologies means it can be challenging to definitively and universally classify a company or investment under a sustainable investing label and there may be areas where such companies and investments could improve or where adverse ESG- related impacts or ESG controversies exist. The evolving nature of sustainable finance related regulations and the development of jurisdiction- specific regulatory criteria also means that there is likely to be a degree of divergence as to the interpretation of such terms in the market. We expect industry guidance, market practice, and regulations in this field to continue to evolve.
